report_title: Online Beer, Wine & Liquor Sales in the US
executive_summary: The online beer, wine and liquor sales industry has seen skyrocketing growth alongside rising per capita disposable income and consumer awareness of online alcohol sales. Mobile internet connections have expanded the potential consumer base. The pandemic provided an opportunity as states loosened regulations on direct-to-consumer alcohol shipments. Over the past five years, revenue surged at a 16.5% CAGR, expected to reach $3.1 billion in 2024 with 4% growth.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Online alcohol sales ease into common practice
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Online alcohol retailers saw booming sales during the pandemic as consumers turned to e-commerce. As the pandemic eased, sales remain above pre-pandemic levels but have normalized as consumers return to pre-pandemic shopping habits. The pool of potential new customers has dwindled, leading to heightened competition.

Regulations around direct-to-consumer alcohol shipments have eased in recent years, expanding the potential consumer market. However, regulations remain stricter for beer and spirits compared to wine. Stricter spirit regulations hinder higher-priced sales for online retailers.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Asset-light business models attract new entrants
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Many emerging online alcohol retailers act as intermediaries between physical stores and consumers, outsourcing delivery to avoid inventory costs and stringent liquor laws. This asset-light model has been successful, benefiting sales and profit.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Younger consumers lifted but are shrinking market
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The youngest legal drinking age group (18-34) helped boost online sales but is shrinking as a revenue share. Older demographics like 35-54 year olds now make up a larger share as younger consumers have less funds for alcohol purchases.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Novelty of online sales will wane
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: In previous years, explosive growth came as consumers discovered online platforms. Moving forward, sales will slow to a more modest rate as the novelty wears off and the customer pool stabilizes. Unlicensed retailers acting as middlemen will grow.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Shifting regulatory landscape continues opportunities and threats
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Easing regulations will allow expansion for online retailers but also increase competition from producers like wineries and distilleries selling direct-to-consumer. Larger retailers may expand market control.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Consumer preferences are difficult to predict
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Predicting consumer tastes is challenging but changes are guaranteed. Retailers must stay ahead of trends like rising popularity of craft spirits and health consciousness. Substitutes like marijuana-infused products may siphon sales.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Excise taxes to sink but competition may limit profit expansion
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Declining excise taxes will reduce purchase costs for retailers. Those with stable customer bases can increase profits, while others facing high competition may need to pass savings to customers to retain them.

industry_definition: The Online Beer, Wine and Liquor Sales industry comprises operators that sell prepackaged beer, wine and liquor through online stores. This industry also includes companies that sell online as a complement to physical storefronts.

positive_impact_factors: High - Steady Barriers To Entry Level

key_trends: Online liquor stores stock craft and specialty beverages to gain a competitive edge. Having a broader product selection attracts modern consumers seeking unique drinks.

Easing regulations have intensified competition from supermarkets and grocery stores. More states are permitting these retailers to sell alcohol and consumers often prefer to purchase alcohol alongside other groceries.

Regulatory shifts present mixed outcomes. Easing regulations offer growth opportunities but also introduce challenges as competition increases, particularly from wineries' and distilleries' direct-to-consumer models. These changes necessitate strategic adaptations.
A shift in market demographics spurs many to adapt. Younger consumers initially boosted online alcohol sales but are now spending less, with older demographics increasing their market share.
Leading online alcohol retailers focus their sights on mobile sales
Online alcohol retailers don't always need a liquor license
Regulations for online alcohol retailers vary by state
Most online beer, wine and liquor retailers didn't need COVID-19 assistance since demand skyrocketed
Purchase costs dominate online alcohol retailers' cost structures
The boom in business has enabled online alcohol sellers to boost profits

market_segmentation.segment_description: This market segment includes consumers between the ages of 18 and 34. This demographic's exposure to technology and digital media drove them to online beer, wine and liquor sales before their older cohorts.

This segment includes individuals between the ages of 35 and 54. Compared with other demographics, consumers in this segment are more likely to have stable sources of income and some savings developed, enabling them to purchase costlier brands and with greater frequency.

The oldest consumer market segment represents consumers aged 55 and older. While some in the segment remain in the workforce and with young families, many are retired individuals living on fixed incomes and enjoying more free time than slightly younger consumers. The mix of lifestyles makes for a somewhat contradictory market.
Other markets include businesses, government entities and similar groupings that typically use online beer, wine and liquor stores to obtain large quantities of alcohol for events and parties.

products_and_services.product_description: The wine product segment includes all varieties of wine sold through online beer, wine and liquor sellers. The segment accounts for the greatest share of revenue.

The beer segment includes beers ranging from domestic brands to niche craft varieties. The segment enjoyed explosive growth during the craft beer boom, but with the industry reaching saturation, much excitement around the beverage has fizzled.

The liquor segment includes spirits ranging from vodka to bourbon and tequila. On average, spirits carry the highest price tag, generating robust sales, but buyers are less likely to purchase spirits in bulk from online retailers or as frequently as options like beer and RTD beverages.

The other segment includes alcoholic beverages, which are excluded from other segments. The most notable examples include ready-to-drink (RTD) beverages, nonalcoholic mixers and miscellaneous products, like lighters, souvenirs and varied kitchenware.

tier_1_suppliers: Wine & Spirits Wholesaling in the US
tier_1_buyers: Single Location Full-Service Restaurants in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Per capita disposable income determines an individual's ability to purchase goods or services. It is calculated by taking income earned from all sources, minus taxes, savings and some non-tax payments and dividing it by the total US population. Though alcohol sustains somewhat evergreen demand, consumers will reduce such purchases when disposable income weakens or opt for less costly brands, posing a potential threat to retailers.

business_locations.location_description: Tech-savvy regions like California, renowned for being a global technology capital, host the highest number of online alcohol retailers in the United States, benefiting from advanced infrastructure and market opportunities.
The Southeast, home to over a quarter of the US population, offers an ideal location for alcohol warehouses aiming to minimize transportation costs and optimize distribution efficiency.
Urban hubs in the Mid-Atlantic, such as Philadelphia and New York City, exhibit low car ownership rates, making residents more reliant on delivery services for their daily needs, including liquor.
Diverse regions including Michigan and Ohio with significant online retail activity.
Home to innovative retail strategies leveraging tech-savvy consumers.
Regions characterized by outdoor activities and local markets with online sales growth.
Flatlands with lower population density and emerging online retail spaces.
Cultured regions with advancing online alcohol sales mixed with historical retail patterns.

regulations_points.regulation_description: After prohibition ended, nearly all states created a stringent framework to monitor alcoholic beverage distribution and ensure the collection of taxes along the supply chain.
Individual states abide by one of two regulatory environments: open and control. In open states, the distribution and retail of alcohol are run by independent companies.
Online beer, wine, and liquor stores need a liquor license to retail alcohol. The process for obtaining a license differs by state.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Industry assistance level is none - steady.

factors_increased_barrier: Industry assistance level is none - steady

basis_points.basis_title: Broader product selection attracts modern consumers
basis_points.basis_description: Online liquor stores stock craft and specialty beverages to gain a competitive edge.
Easing regulations have intensified competition from supermarkets and grocery stores.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchase Costs Inflate Despite Lower Alcohol Prices
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Online alcohol retailers contend with substantial purchase costs.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Packaging material prices have swelled in recent years
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Packaging material prices have swelled in recent years.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Though online beer, wine and liquor sellers seldom require heavy investment in machinery, they must quickly secure extensive inventories.

volatility_points.volatility_title: CONSUMER TRENDS AND RELEVANT LAWS DRIVE REVENUE FLUCTUATIONS
volatility_points.volatility_description: Frequent changes in consumer preferences for various types of beverages significantly impact sales.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Mobile Applications Drive Growth in Online Alcohol Sales
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: While mobile apps aren't anything new, online liquor stores have only just begun to embrace mobile sales over the past five years.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in one corner of the market or do you retail a diversified range of products?
FAQs.answer: New companies have an asset-light business model where they primarily work as intermediaries.

FAQs.question: Are your customers heavily price-conscious?
FAQs.answer: Customers, especially millennials, prefer convenience of service more than the price.

FAQs.question: What steps do you take to retain talented employees with specialized knowledge?
FAQs.answer: Operators have increasingly relied on skilled employees such as computer and software engineers.

FAQs.question: Has your company explored acquisition opportunities in order to expand reach and reduce overhead expenses?
FAQs.answer: Large e-commerce companies such as Amazon have acquired smaller startups to enter the industry.

FAQs.question: How does your company utilize new technology, such as RFID tags in its operations?
FAQs.answer: There has a been a vast increase in usage of RFID technology in this industry.

FAQs.question: Does your company use point-of-sale (POS) systems to ensure that the most popular products are kept in stock?
FAQs.answer: New companies in the industry have completely relied on technological and IT infrastructure to conduct business.

FAQs.question: Do you work with trade associations or other interest groups to advance your company's interests?
FAQs.answer: Customers will increasingly advocate local state governments to liberalize stringent alcohol laws.

FAQs.question: What does your company do to remain compliant with new consumer regulations?
FAQs.answer: Companies have to be compliant with both federal and state and in some cases, local county laws.

FAQs.question: How do your company's profit margins compare to your main competitors'?
FAQs.answer: As economies of scale of startups increased, profitability has followed suit.

FAQs.question: What challenges did your company face amid supply chain disruptions?
FAQs.answer: Demand for industry services increases as supply chain disruptions ease up and return back to normal.

FAQs.question: How do you maintain optimum stock levels?
FAQs.answer: Controlling stock is important for industry players, as it helps them ensure prompt delivery of purchased online goods.

FAQs.question: Is your company dominant in any particular regional markets?
FAQs.answer: Being located close to key markets will help industry players reduce transportation costs.

FAQs.question: How do you ensure your online platform and/or app is easy to use and navigate?
FAQs.answer: The quality and accessibility of consumer websites are crucial to ensure efficient browsing and transactions for online purchases.

FAQs.question: What regulation is in place in regard to online alcohol retailing in your state?
FAQs.answer: An increase in regulation for alcoholic beverages dampens industry revenue due to increased operating costs.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor per capita expenditure on alcohol in the United States?
FAQs.answer: A rise in per capita expenditure on alcohol indicates greater overall alcohol consumption.

FAQs.question: Do you track fluctuations in per capita disposable income?
FAQs.answer: As per capita disposable income rises, more consumers are better able to purchase fine wines, liquors and beers.
